Certainly! The Criterion Collection has a vast collection of films, and there are many lesser-known gems that are worth discovering. Here are a few recommendations:

1. The Battle of Algiers (1966) - A gritty and intense film about the Algerian struggle for independence from France. It's a powerful and politically charged work that has become a touchstone for many other films.

2. A Brighter Summer Day (1991) - A Taiwanese film directed by Edward Yang that tells the story of a group of teenagers in 1960s Taiwan. It's a poignant and lyrical work that explores the anxieties and desires of young people in a rapidly changing society.

3. The Ascent (1977) - A Russian film directed by Larisa Shepitko that depicts the harrowing journey of two Soviet soldiers during World War II. It's a brutal and haunting film that explores the human cost of war and the struggle for survival.

4. Black Narcissus (1947) - A British film directed by Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger that tells the story of a group of nuns who struggle to maintain their faith in the face of temptation and desire in the Himalayas. It's a visually stunning and emotionally resonant work that explores themes of religion, sexuality, and colonialism.

5. The Exterminating Angel (1962) - A Mexican film directed by Luis Buñuel that tells the story of a group of upper-class guests who become trapped in a room and begin to lose their minds. It's a surreal and darkly humorous work that challenges our assumptions about class and society.

These are just a few examples of the many lesser-known films in The Criterion Collection that are worth discovering. Each of these works offers a unique and unforgettable cinematic experience that is sure to leave a lasting impression.
